bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Lunsford D. Fricks, January 21, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] informs Fricks of the regulations for impounded waters and comments on papers submitted.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Lunsford D. Fricks, January 21, 1923
div1.opener:
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.
N.M.C
I W
Fricks
Washington, D. C.,
January 21, 1923.
Surgeon L. D. Fricks,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Room 17, Court House Building,
Memphis, Tenn.
Dear Doctor Fricks:
div1.p:
The Office of the Surgeon General of the Army has returned the
papers I sent them. I therefor gave your letter of Tuesday last
and its enclosures to Dr. Stimson. His present intention is to
leave the matter of regulations for impounded water to be presented
to the Federal Power Commission in statu quo awaiting the result
of further investigations.

In the mean time he says their (F. P. C.) policy is to have
the measures requisite for each project determined for that project
after examination. Except for the Muscle Shoals work, apparently
there are no considerable number of other pools in contemplation in
malarial districts.

You asked my opinion of the paper submitted: I agree with you
in tI think some provision should be made to control the spread of
malaria by carriers--exactly what may be a question. This is the
only difference between this paper and the one you sent me in October.
I think both papers could be changed to their advantage, indeed, it
is hard to draw satisfactory regulations for any industry without con-
sultation with the industry affected: Just as we, in the quarantine
regulations, have always had in consultation shipping merchants:
masters of vessels and immigration men, so that the economic as well
as well
-2-
as the sanitary side can be considered.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General
On Waiting Orders.
